The rock bounced off a low hanging branch. By throwing the rocks with 
her beak she'd lost much of her accuracy. It landed about three feet 
to his left. By hiding herself in the foliage she'd given up most of 
her flying advantages. How to get up to where she was on the other 
hand, was Lunarpines main disadvantage. She thought out her strategy 
well this time. If he could teach her to use those skills in a real 
battle she would easily survive every time.

"If I'd wanted to fight rocks then I wouldn't have needed a sparring 
partner. So Come out and fight you overstuffed hummingbird." he was 
hoping to rattle her nerves, make her stop thinking for a few 
seconds. A wolf can't climb trees, but a bot can, all he needed was 
for her to lose her temper and give him an opening.

--- In nbwrpg@egroups.com, logomorph@h... wrote:
> (Gee thanks)
> ::Shadow Wing::
> 
> She stayed in the tree.  She could use the daggers, but he would 
> still have the upper hand on physical strength. She needed an 
> equalizer to make things more even.  But she didn't want to hurt 
him 
> in the prossess.  She flew to another tree a few yards off and 
> perched high in the branches.  She figured if she waited, he would 
> show her how to win. She took out a stone and tossed it at him.
> 
> 
> --- In nbwrpg@egroups.com, cyberwolf4@p... wrote:
> > "Slag I missed again." Lunarpine watched her fly to tree number 
> two, 
> > heard the hoot and saw her head in the direction of the third 
tree 
> > before seemingly vanishing in the thick branches and leaves. He 
> moved 
> > right and cut through some thick bushes.
> > He opened his comm "What's the matter birdie you afraid to take 
me 
> > claw to claw, I'll even let you use your daggers if you want." 
> > Transforming back to wolf mode he stayed low. He could easily 
pick 
> > her off with a rifle blast, but that would defeat the purpose of 
> the 
> > sparring.
> > (Much better Logo.)
> > 
> > 
> > --- In nbwrpg@egroups.com, logomorph@h... wrote:
> > > :Shadow Wing::
> > > 
> > > She stayed hovering up over the fallen tree.  She knew he could 
> see 
> > > her now.  So she flew over to another tree and perched.  She 
> hooted 
> > > at him. She figured she would be nice and let him know where 
she 
> > was.
> > > 
> > > She knew that she couldn't compete physically with him, so why 
> not 
> > > have some fun before getting her tail feathers kicked.
> > > 
> > > She hooted a few more time and flew to another tree. She 
perched 
> on 
> > a 
> > > high branch with thick foliage. Only this time,she held 
perfectly 
> > > still and didn't make a sound.
